text:
LOOKING TOWARD GOTHAM FROM THE TRIBORO BRIDGE TOWER.

Astoria, L.I. ---- A Panorama of Manhatten spires greets this ironworker as he looks toward the New York skyline from the Astoria tower of the Triboro Bridge. The project, started 16 years ago, will be finished in 1936. Through government funds it has given jobs to 18,000 men. The series of bridges will connect Manhatten, Brooklyn, and the Bronx and will be one of the greatest projects of its kind in engineering history.

International News Photo

1934

title: Bridges - Triborough Bridge.

text:
(1)
Triboro Bridge, west from foreground at about 24th Street, showing at the left Hoyt Avenue South viewed west. In the center is the site upon which the arches for the support of the Approach to the bridge are to be constructed.

P. L. Sperr.

September 20, 1934.

(2)
The same, further west, showing at the right 21st Street, viewed north to the Hell Gate Bridge Approach. Also shown is the north side of Hoyt Avenue North beyond the Triboro arches.

P. L. Sperr.

June 12, 1935.

(3)
The same, a northwest view, showing also in the background the Hell Gate Bridge.

P. L. Sperr.

June 12, 1935.

(3 views, not dry mount items.)

text:
(1)
Triboro Bridge. A northerly view showing from back to foreground the Gas Tanks of the Astoria Light, Heat and Power Company ; the Approach to the Hell Gate Bridge, and the excavation for the supports to the Triboro Bridge. The last two are in Astoria Park.
June 12, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, looking south, showing the Triboro Tower in Astoria Park. Beyond it is Pot Cove; a part of Hell Gate which is a part
of the East River.
June 12, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2 views, not dry mount items.)

text:
(1)
Triboro and Hell Gate Bridges. In view No. 1 is seen from fore to background the above named bridges. In the foreground is the Triboro(under construction). The Hell Gate is shown spanning the east channel between Wards Island (left) and Astoria Park, Queens (right). The roadway shown skirting the river's edge is Shore Boulevard; the view being northward.

P. L. Sperr.
June 12, 1935.

(2)
The same, viewed westward from a point of vantage in Astoria Park.

P. L. Sperr.
June 12, 1935.

(3)
Another view showing a more advanced stage of construction.

P. L. Sperr.
November 9, 1935.
(3 views, not dry mount items.)

text:
(1)
Triboro Bridge, west from elevated station of the Astoria lines, at Twenty-fifth Ave. and 31st Street. On the left side of the approach is Hoyt Ave South; on the right is the future Hoyt Ave. North. Intersecting streets are: 30th, 29th, and 28th Streets. The arched span shown has an anchorage in Astoria Park.

November 9, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing also in the right background the Hell Gate Bridge; a railroad structure that parallels this new span.

November 9, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same at 27th Street and Hoyt Ave.; a point of vantage slightly westward.

June 12, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
(3 views, not dry mount items).

text:
The Triboro and the Hellgate Bridges as viewed from the air and spanning the east channel of the East River.

To the left is Wards Island and to the right Astoria, Queens. Beyond is the Hunts Pont section of the Bronx (left), Rikers Island (center), Bowery Bay, Flushing Bay and the College Point-Whitestone section of Queens. View No. 3 is a duplicate of No. 2 tho darker.

W. P. A. Photo
Five Boroughs Project

1937
Views: 1-2-3
title: Bridges - Triborough and Hell Gate Bridges - [East River.]

text:
(1) The Triborough Bridge and Approach, as seen from the Hoyt Ave. Station of the Second Ave. Elevated Line. The view is westward towards the East River and Manhattan, beyond.

January 1937.

George D. Chinn.

(2) The same, and slightly northward. Also shown is the arched span of the Hell Gate Bridge of the New York Central R.R.

January 1937.

George D. Chinn.

(3) The tollgate and tower at the junction of the Manhattan and Bronx Approach's to the bridge proper.

January 1937.

George D. Chinn.

(4) A view southward along the Harlem River from the Manhattan (East 125th Street) Approach.

January 1937.

George D. Chinn.

(5) The Bridge Approach from the East River Drive and bypass (uncompleted). On the left appears Pleasant Ave., south from 122nd Street.

January 1937.

George D. Chinn.
